Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the rate of supplementary benefit payable to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 5; how this assessment was carried out; and if he will explain the rate of benefit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned exhausted his title to unemployment benefit on 30 March 1983 after which he claimed unemployment assistance.

His case was referred to a social welfare officer for investigation of his means. The investigating officer interviewed the applicant and obtained details of the income of the household which comprise two parents who are working and one other non-earning person. The net income of the parents less the amount of rent payable and a set allowance for each parent was divided between the two non-earning members of the household and the sum so calculated was assessed at £25 weekly as being the advantage accruing to him of living and lodging in his parents' home. He was accordingly entitled to unemployment assistance at £1.25 weekly being the maximum rate £26.25 less £25 and payments were made to him as they became due. He has appealed against the assessment of his means and arrangements are being made to have his case determined by an appeals officer. The rate of unemployment assistance payable to him will be reviewed in the light of the decision of the appeals officer.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when disability benefit will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Cork who applied approximately six weeks ago; and the reason for the delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned has been paid disability benefit from 16 September 1982, fourth day of incapacity, to 7 May 1983, and there has been no undue delay in issuing payment of benefit. Arrangements have been made to pay him at regular weekly intervals while medical certificates are only required on a monthly basis. Pay-related benefit was also paid from 27 September 1982, thirteenth day of incapacity, up to 2 April 1983. However, the Social Welfare Act, 1983, provides that pay-related benefit is not payable where the total amount of disability and pay-related benefit equals or exceeds 80% of a claimant's average reckonable weekly earnings in the relevant tax year, which in this case is the 1980-81 tax year.

Disability benefit in payment equalled 80% of the claimant's reckonable weekly earnings and he therefore ceased to be entitled to pay-related benefit from 4 April 1983. He continues, however, to receive flat-rate disability benefit of £59.65 weekly which is the maximum rate for a married couple with one dependent child.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Under the regulations the rate of pay-related benefit payable with flat-rate unemployment benefit to an applicant is governed by the total of her reckonable earnings during the relevant income tax period.

The entitlement to pay-related benefit of the person concerned is governed by her reckonable earnings during the income tax period 6 April 1981 to 5 April 1982. She was not, however, fully employed during the period as she was absent through illness from 2 April 1981 to 12 August 1981. The amount of her reckonable earnings was for this reason less than those of her sister and consequently the amount of pay-related benefit to which she was entitled was also less than that of her sister whose reckonable earnings were greater because she had been fully employed during the period 6 April 1981 to April 1982.

Pay-related benefit, as the name implies, is related to the earnings of a claimant and is determined on that basis and not on length of service. The circumstances of the two persons mentioned by the Deputy in the question are not similar and the correct amount of pay-related benefit is being paid in each case.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if all inspections for cattle headage payments will be carried out before the end of September 1983 so that the price of store cattle will not become depressed as a result of the excessive number of cattle being offered for sale in late harvest and early winter.

Speaker.P: Cattle inspections are commencing on 4 July this year, some seven weeks earlier than in 1982, and are scheduled to be completed by end October — as compared with mid-December last year.

Given the manpower available in my Department, completion of all inspections by end September is impossible but the earlier commencement of inspections this year should help to alleviate the peaking problem mentioned by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason for the delay in paying farm modernisation grants to a person (details supplied) in County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The grant in this case has been paid.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will arrange to pay a grant under the farm modernisation scheme to a person (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: There is no grant outstanding in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Estate Acquisition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if the Land Commission will acquire an estate (details supplied) in County Galway which adjoins an estate already acquired by the Commission; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The Land Commission have no proposals for the acquisition of these lands.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when an EEC cattle headage grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The person named will be paid his cattle headage grant under the 1982 disadvantaged areas schemes as soon as the batch which includes his payment is processed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Estate Acquisition.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if it is the intention of the Land Commission to acquire an estate (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The Land Commission have no proposals for the acquisition of these lands.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when a farm modernisation scheme grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: A revised farm plan providing for building works under the farm modernisation scheme was received from ACOT on 24 March 1983.

As announced in the budget, grants under the farm modernisation scheme for buildings and fixed assets have been suspended until later in the year. Accordingly no further action is being taken regarding the works in question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when a payment under the EEC scheme for premiums for good quality ewes for 1982-83 will be made to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: My Department have no record of receipt of an application under the scheme of premiums for good quality ewes 1982-83 from the persons named.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he intends to provide a 24-hour service at Cashel Garda station, County Tipperary; and, if so, when he proposes to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The precise arrangements made for policing particular areas are a matter for the Garda authorities, who report that the divisional officer is arranging that Cashel station will remain open until 12 midnight each day, instead of 5 p.m. as at present, when an extra garda becomes available for assignment there later this month. The authorities have no proposals at present for any further extension of the opening hours but the policing arrangements for the Cashel area will be kept under review.

There are, of course, arrangments for providing a police service for the Cashel area from the district headquarters at Cahir when the local station is closed and the area also receives attention from mobile patrols operated by plainclothes units from Thurles and Clonmel stations and the traffic corps based at Thurles.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Donegal Company Investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if the Garda Fraud Squad is investigation the affairs of a company (details supplied) in County Donegal; and, if so, if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am informed by the Garda authorities that they have received certain complaints about the affairs of the company in question and that those complaints are being investigated. The results of the investigation will, if necessary, be communicated to the Director of Public Prosecutions for a decision.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kerry Title Registration Application.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Begley Mr. Begley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason for the delay in completing a Land Registry dealing for a person (details supplied) in County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): This is an application for registration of title acquired by long possession of registered land. The application was lodged in the Land Registry on 19 August 1981. Applications such as this are usually of a complex nature and require extensive examination of title involving prolonged correspondence with the applicants' solicitors. I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that the examination has been finalised in this case and that statutory notices issued to interested parties on 26 April 1983. These parties have been given until 13 May 1983 to object to the proposed registration. If no objection is received by that date registration will be completed as quickly as possible thereafter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Tipperary New Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether a Garda station will be provided at Gortnahoe village, Thurles, County Tipperary, in the near future, in view of the very high incidence of vandalism in the area; and, if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The precise arrangements made for the policing of particular areas are a matter for the Garda authorities, who state that they consider that the current arrangement whereby the Gortnahoe area is served from Urlingford station, supplemented by assistance from Killenaule station and the District Headquarters at Thurles, makes the best use of Garda resources and provides an adequate service. The Garda authorities also say that they have had no recent reports of vandalism in the Gortnahoe area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hilliard Mr. Hilliard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will clarify whether parents who are holders of medical cards have free transport for their children to the nearest (a) secondary post-primary school, (b) technical post-primary school and (c) community post-primary school, when no such school is in their catchment area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Parents who hold medical cards and whose children are eligible under the post-primary school transport scheme, may be excused the post-primary school transport contribution if their children are attending their appropriate post-primary centre. A centre is not deemed to be inappropriate merely because it does not contain a particular category of post-primary school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the highly unsatisfactory conditions obtaining for students and staff at Scoil Íde, Finglas, Dublin; and when normal present day standards will be provided for the students and staff who have endured this situation for so long.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The position in relation to Scoil Íde, Finglas, is that my Department are prepared to approve the upgrading, where necessary of the school's existing accommodation to a satisfactory level.
Officials from my Department's building unit have arranged to discuss at an early date the matter with the Chief Executive Officer of the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Limerick New National School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the progress made to date in regard to providing a new national school for Kilcolman, County Limerick, on the free site being provided for this purpose.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed in principle to the provision of additional accommodation at Kilcolman national school, County Limerick, and has requested the Commissioners of Public Works to report on the matter. When the Commissioners report has been received and considered, a decision will be conveyed to the chairman without delay.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the date on which her predecessor made the decision to authorise school transport for children from the Drummond area to Mountmellick, County Laois, which has always been accepted as the natural catchment for this area; if she is aware that 12 children from the area have not yet been provided with transport; and if she will make immediate arrangements to have such transport provided in accordance with the decision approved and confirmed to a deputation from the area by her predecessor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Drummond is in the Clonaslee catchment area. The transport arrangements for pupils from the Clonaslee area provide full transport facilities for senior cycle pupils from the area who attend the Mountmellick centre. Eligible junior cycle pupils from the Clonaslee area who attend school in Mountmellick may be carried as concessionary catchment boundary pupils to Mountmellick, within the limits of the spare capacity on the existing service. My Department have no authority to incur additional expenditure to facilitate catchment boundary pupils beyond the number for which space is available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the progress made to date in relation to the planning and provision of an extension to the boys national school at Graiguenamanagh, County Kilkenny; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: It is proposed to replace the present boy's national school at Graiguenamanagh, County Kilkenny, by a new school building. A report on the suitability of the site offered by the school authorities is awaited from the Commissioners of Public Works.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hilliard Mr. Hilliard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when work will commence on the extension to Boardsmill national school, Trim, County Meath.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A grant was sanctioned on 19 July 1982 towards the cost of the proposed extension to Boardsmill (Batterstown) national school, County Meath. The further planning arrangements leading up to the invitation of tenders are a matter for the Commissioners of Public Works. It is not possible at this stage to say when building may commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Intermediate Certificate Examination Applicant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will allow a person (details supplied) in Dublin 9 to sit his intermediate certificate examination at Plunkett School, Whitehall, Dublin, as he was refused originally on the grounds that he was under age; and if she will make a special concession in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The rules governing the age of transfer to post-primary school and of entry to the certificate examinations were drawn up after consultations with the various interested bodies. The rules allow the intermediate certificate examination to be taken at 14½ years and the leaving certificate examination as early as 16½ years of age. I appreciate the Deputy's concern in the case of the individual pupil concerned but I trust that it will be appreciated that in the general interest of pupils in connection with the maintenance of standards it is necessary to prescribe a minimum age limit for admission to the intermediate certificate examination.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Galway New Second Level School.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the position regarding a second-level school to cater for the Renmore, Mervue and Ballybane areas in Galway City.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department are in communication with the local authorities with a view to obtaining a suitable site for a new second-level school at Ballybane, Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason school transport has not been arranged for a person (details supplied) in County Offaly who paid the money for her ticket last January.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Transport in accordance with the standards applied under the terms of the school transport scheme is available to this pupil. This is subject to the payment of the appropriate transport contribution of £14 in respect of the Easter to Summer term which applies to a junior cycle pupil who attends his or her appropriate post-primary centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware that Curraheen national school, Glenbeigh, County Kerry, has been closed because it is in disrepair; if she is aware that the children in the area must now walk a distance of five miles to the nearest school; if so, if she will arrange free public transport for them as a matter of urgency; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The Department have received no request to provide transport for the pupils in question. If full details are forwarded to the Department through the chairman of the board of management, the matter will be considered.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Dublin School Building Work.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position of the second stage of Brookfield primary school, Tallaght, County Dublin; and when work will commence on the school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The question of providing a second primary school at Brookfield, Tallaght, County Dublin, is under active consideration in my Department at present. A decision will be conveyed to the chairman as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Cork School Heating Grant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. O'Keeffe Mr. N. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a special heating grant will be paid in respect of Glenahulla national school, Mitchelstown, County Cork; and if he will give a detailed explanation on why payment is not being made, as it has been outstanding for some time and numerous representations have been made; and if he is aware that the matter is the cause of great dissatisfaction among the parents.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Tenders for improved heating and lighting services at Glenahulla national school, County Cork, were submitted in error by the chairman's consultants to the Office of Public Works. They have been received in my Department and are being examined. A decision will be conveyed to the chairman at an early date.
